title: Already in a letter of 1221, Frederick makes reference to “Nuceria Christianorum”—Lucera of the Christians. It is possible that he thereby designates, through a circumlocution disavowing the Muslims’ presence, precisely Muslim Lucera; or that he uses the name to refer speciWcally to the Christian institutions—in particular, the churches and their personnel and Wnancial holdings—in the process of being displaced
See Frederick’s letter to Pope Gregory defending his Arab policy in Lucera: Huillard-Bréholles and de Luynes

Pietro Egidi assumes that Lucera and the surrounding territory were underpopulated (Egidi, La colonia saracena di Lucera e la sua distruzione, 10). Jean-Marie Martin, in a more recent article on Lucera, disagrees with Egidi on this point, asserting that the region was populated and thus attributing to Frederick’s constitution of the Muslim colony there a more aggressive quality (Martin, “La colonie sarrasine de Lucera et son environnement
Chronica, 216; Huillard-Bréholles and de Luynes
